conclusion: Determine the kinetic energy Ek of the second particle when it leaves the velocity selector N.
The first particle with mass m and charge q passes through the velocity selector N along a straight line, meaning electric force qE and magnetic force qvB are balanced.
Since qE = qvB, it implies E = vB.
The velocity v of the first particle can be found using the relationship between the electric field E and the potential difference U in the accelerator M.
The potential difference U accelerates the particle from rest to velocity v, so the kinetic energy gained is (1/2)mv^2.
By the work-energy theorem, qU = (1/2)mv^2 implies v = sqrt(2qU/m).
Since E = vB, substituting v gives E = sqrt(2qU/m) B.

The second particle has a mass 2m and the same charge q. The electric force and the magnetic force on this particle must also be balanced for it to pass through the velocity selector N along a straight line.
Using the relationship qE = qv'B, we get v' = E/B = sqrt(2qU/m).
The velocity v' of the second particle is the same as the velocity v of the first particle.
The second particle deviates by a distance d in the velocity selector N.
The radius of the circular path of the particle in the magnetic field is given by r = mv'/qB = sqrt(2mU)/qB.
The deviation d is the difference in the vertical distances traveled by the particle in the time it takes to travel a horizontal distance equal to the width of the velocity selector.
